page.title: 04Ballingry long ago
page.content: Many of our great-grandparents came to this area from other coal fields where work had ceased. Before World War Two, the houses were next to the pits. They had a big range to heat water for the miners to have a wash in a zinc tub as there were no pit-head baths then. Toilets were at the end of the garden. There are still miners' rows to be seen in Lochore. People left school at 14 and started work straight away, as there was plenty of work in the pits then. The people went to corner shops and delivery vans came round. There were no supermarkets like today. The main transport was buses, trams and trains from Lochgelly. Lochore Meadows, known locally as the "Meadies", was a mess of pit bings and rubbish tips. Hazel Duffy (9)
